'''Ethics''', sometimes known as '''moral philosophy'''', is a branch of [[philosophy]] that involves systematizing, defending and recommending concepts of right and wrong [[action (philosophy)|conduct]], often addressing disputes of [[moral diversity]].<ref name="iep.utm.edu">''Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy'': [http://www.iep.utm.edu/ethics/ "Ethics"]</ref> The term comes from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] word ἠθικός ''ethikos'' from ἦθος ''[[ethos]]'', which means "custom, [[habit]]". The superfield within philosophy known as [[axiology]] includes both ethics and [[aesthetics]] and is unified by each sub-branch's concern with value.<ref>''[[Random House Unabridged Dictionary]]'': [http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/axiology Entry on Axiology.]</ref> Philosophical ethics investigates what is the best way for humans to live, and what kinds of actions are right or wrong in particular circumstances.
